title: Italian cruiser Goito
text:
Goito was a <a href="torpedo%20cruiser">torpedo cruiser</a> built for the Italian "<a href="Regia%20Marina">Regia Marina</a>" (Royal Navy) in the 1880s. She was the <a href="lead%20ship">lead ship</a> of the , which included three other vessels. "Goito" was built by the <a href="Regio%20Cantiere%20di%20Castellammare%20di%20Stabia">Regio Cantiere di Castellammare di Stabia</a> shipyard between September 1885 and February 1888. She was armed with a variety of light guns and five <a href="torpedo%20tube">torpedo tube</a>s, and was capable of a top speed of . The ship served the duration of her career in the main Italian fleet. Her early service was primarily occupied with training exercises; front-line duties ended in 1897 when she was converted into a <a href="minelayer">minelayer</a>, though she continued to participate in fleet exercises. During <a href="World%20War%20I">World War I</a>, "Goito" laid defensive minefields in the <a href="Adriatic%20Sea">Adriatic Sea</a>. She was eventually sold for scrap in 1920 and <a href="ship%20breaking">broken up</a>.
Design.
"Goito" was <a href="length%20overall">long overall</a> and had a <a href="beam%20%28nautical%29">beam</a> of and an average <a href="draft%20%28hull%29">draft</a> of . She <a href="displacement%20%28ship%29">displaced</a> normally. Her propulsion system consisted of three <a href="compound%20engine">double-expansion</a> <a href="steam%20engine">steam engine</a>s each driving a single <a href="screw%20propeller">screw propeller</a>, with steam supplied by six coal-fired <a href="locomotive%20boiler">locomotive boiler</a>s. Exact figures for the ship's performance have not survived, but the members of the "Goito" class could steam at a speed of about from . "Goito" had a cruising radius of at a speed of . She had a crew of between 105 and 121.
The primary armament for "Goito" was five <a href="torpedo%20tube">torpedo tube</a>s. She carried a light gun <a href="battery%20%28artillery%29">battery</a> for defense against <a href="torpedo%20boat">torpedo boat</a>s. This consisted of five <a href="QF%206-pounder%20Hotchkiss"></a> 40-<a href="caliber%20%28artillery%29">caliber</a> guns, two 20-cal. guns, and three 37 mm revolving <a href="Hotchkiss%20gun">Hotchkiss gun</a>s, all mounted singly. The ship was protected with an armored <a href="deck%20%28ship%29">deck</a> that was thick.
Service history.
"Goito" was built by the <a href="Regio%20Cantiere%20di%20Castellammare%20di%20Stabia">Regio Cantiere di Castellammare di Stabia</a> shipyard; her <a href="keel">keel</a> was <a href="keel%20laying">laid down</a> in September 1885 and her completed <a href="hull%20%28watercraft%29">hull</a> was <a href="ship%20launching">launched</a> on 6 July 1887. She was completed on 16 February 1888 and <a href="ship%20commissioning">commissioned</a> into the fleet, the first member of her class to enter service. That year, she took part in the annual fleet maneuvers, along with five <a href="ironclad%20warship">ironclads</a>, a <a href="protected%20cruiser">protected cruiser</a>, the torpedo cruisers , , and , and numerous smaller vessels. The maneuvers consisted of close-order drills and a simulated attack on and defense of La Spezia. Later that year, the ship was present during a naval review held for the German Kaiser <a href="Wilhelm%20II">Wilhelm II</a> during a visit to Italy.
The ship served in the 3rd Division of the Active Squadron during the 1893 fleet maneuvers, along with the ironclads and and four <a href="torpedo%20boat">torpedo boat</a>s. During the maneuvers, which lasted from 6 August to 5 September, the ships of the Active Squadron simulated a French attack on the Italian fleet. The following year, the ship took part in the annual fleet maneuvers in the 1st Division of the Active Squadron, along with the <a href="ironclad%20battleship">ironclad battleship</a> and the protected cruiser . That year, "Goito" had her coal-fired boilers replaced with oil-fired models, and her center engine and propeller shaft were removed. Her engines now produced for a top speed of .
In 1895, "Goito" was stationed in the 2nd Maritime Department, split between <a href="Taranto">Taranto</a> and <a href="Naples">Naples</a>, along with most of the torpedo cruisers in the Italian fleet. These included her sister ships , , and , the eight s, and "Tripoli". "Goito" was converted into a <a href="minelayer">minelayer</a> in 1897. Her torpedo tubes were removed and equipment to handle sixty <a href="naval%20mine">naval mine</a>s was installed. In 1898, "Goito" was assigned to the Reserve Squadron, which included the ironclads , , and , and three protected cruisers. The following year, she returned to the Active Squadron, where she served with six ironclads, the <a href="armored%20cruiser">armored cruiser</a> , the protected cruiser , and . During the 1907 fleet maneuvers, "Goito" was attached to the main fleet to lay mines at a simulated advance base that would be created during the exercises.
At the outbreak of the <a href="Italo-Turkish%20War">Italo-Turkish War</a> in September 1911, "Goito" was stationed in <a href="Venice">Venice</a> along with "Tripoli" and "Montebello". None of the vessels saw action during the war. Italy had declared neutrality at the start of World War I, but by July 1915, the <a href="Triple%20Entente">Triple Entente</a> had convinced the Italians to enter the war against the <a href="Central%20Powers">Central Powers</a>. Admiral <a href="Paolo%20Thaon%20di%20Revel">Paolo Thaon di Revel</a>, the Italian naval chief of staff, believed that the threat from <a href="Austro-Hungarian%20Navy">Austro-Hungarian</a> <a href="submarine">submarine</a>s and naval mines in the narrow waters of the Adriatic was too serious for him to use the fleet in an active way. Instead, Revel decided to implement a blockade at the relatively safer southern end of the Adriatic with the main fleet, while smaller vessels, such as the <a href="MAS%20%28boat%29">MAS boats</a>, conducted raids on Austro-Hungarian ships and installations. "Goito" was initially used to lay a series of defensive minefields, along with the torpedo cruisers and , in support of this strategy. The ship remained in service until early 1920; she was stricken from the <a href="naval%20register">naval register</a> on 15 March 1920 and subsequently <a href="ship%20breaking">broken up</a> for scrap.
